dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Foreboding organ music is heard... We are looking down at a rough brick floor ... is it an alley? ... a cobblestone street? ... a warehouse? a facto ... we're not sure... The flickering glow of flame is the only illumination... The ominous organ music continues as... From the bottom of the frame... A dark pool of blood slowly begins to spread ... moving u the frame, defying gravity ... the flickering flame refle in the blood... Finally, the pool of blood fills the entire frame.

dialogues.speaker: SUDDENLY--
dialogues.text: A shrill factory whistle blows-- ENORMOUSLY LOUD -- blood-chilling and spine-shattering -- the whistle is a bizarre combination of sound: a factory whistle; a hog being slaughtered; a dog snarling; a roari inferno; a human scream-- And a man's face appears, upside down, reflected in the p of blood. He is THE GENTLEMAN, a slender dandy in pearl grey gloves matching waistcoat. A cold and superior aristocrat. The camera slowly revolves -- the Gentleman becoming righ side up as--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attend the tale of Sweeney Todd. His skin was pale and his eye was odd. He shaved the faces of gentlemen Who never thereafter were heard of again. He trod a path that few have trod, Did Sweeney Todd, The Demon Barber of Fleet Street. We cut from the blood to see the Gentleman standing befor us. Strangely impassive. We are in an eerie dark chamber, unclear, a low ceiling, world of silhouettes and shadows.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Another figure emerges from the miasma of shadows, into t hellish flickering of flame: THE BANKER. He is large, rot and sleek. Impressive muttonchops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kept a shop in London town, Of fancy clients and good renown, And what if none of their souls were saved? They went to their maker impeccably shaved... More FIGURES begin to emerge from the shadows, joining th Gentleman and the Banker as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By Sweeney, By Sweeney Todd, The Demon Barber of Fleet Street. Although prosaic in appearance these figures are, in fact GHOSTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swing your razor wide, Sweeney! Hold it to the skies! Freely flows the blood of those Who moralize! As they continue, the new figures become more distinct... THE GENERAL, a tough, leather-skinned military man in a crimson imperial uniform...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His needs were few, his room was bare: THE PRIEST, a lean, severe man with pale skin in clerical attire...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lavabo and a fancy chair... THE TOURIST, a small, meek man with glasses in an ill-fit suit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mug of suds and a leather strop, An apron, a towel, a pail and a mop... THE STUDENT, a dashing young man from Oxford with luxurio long hair...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For neatness he deserves a nod, Does Sweeney Todd...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street. The ghosts are a bit more insinuating now as they move ar this mysterious world...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (variously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inconspicuous Sweeney was, Quick and quiet and clean `e was. Back of his smile, under his word, Sweeney heard music that nobody heard. Sweeney pondered and Sweeney planned, Like a perfect machine 'e planned, Sweeney was smooth, Sweeney was subtle, Sweeney would blink and rats would scuttle... The specters are becoming more insistent, their strange impassivity giving way to accusation as the flickering re flame becomes an inferno--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (variously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweeney was smooth, Sweeney was subtle, Sweeney would blink and rats would scuttle. Inconspicuous Sweeney was, Quick and quiet and clean 'e was, Like a perfect machine 'e was, Was Sweeney! Sweeney! Sweeney! Sweeeeeneeeeey! On this explosive note we revolve -- away from the ghostl Furies-- To discover-- SWEENEY TODD. Standing before us. An unclear figure, silhouetted in blazing red flames. We slowly push in on him as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attend the tale of Sweeney Todd. He served a dark and a vengeful god. What happened then--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, who's to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he wouldn't want us to give it away,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (variously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not Sweeney, Not Sweeney Todd, The Demon Barber of Fleet Street. On this note, we push in tight on the figure of Todd... Music and the clanging of a clock tower bell are heard as slowly begin pulling back and are imperceptibly transport to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANTHONY, a young sailor of about 20, is standing at the r of a ship. We see the obscure shape of rigging and sails behind him. The cries of sailors echo. Behind him stand the GENTLEMAN and the BANKER. They are looking past Anthony, looking at something. They move awa Anthony peers through the fog, straining to see... London. Gradually, as the ship approaches, the towering spires an mountainous rooftops of the city begin to stand out in relief, to emerge through the fog like a tiger creeping toward its prey. Music continues as Anthony takes in the dreadful and magnificent spectacle of the 19th Century metropolis. The gnarl of rooftops. The labyrinth of streets and alleys. T black trails of smoke reaching up like skeletal fingers f a thousand chimneys. London. Sulfurous London. Anthony is awestruck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have sailed the world, beheld its wonders From the Dardanelles To the mountains of Peru, But there's no place like London--! Then--

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sweeney Todd steps to Anthony's side, grimly interrupting

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, there's no place like London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Todd...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are young. Life has been kind to you. You will learn. Todd's glares forward, his haunted gaze never leaving the approaching city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music continues as Todd stands very still and takes in th shadowy figures on the docks. Anthony seems almost lost at his side, overwhelmed by the scale and aura of the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord ... takes your breath away, doesn't it? Todd shudders violently, almost snarling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a hole in the world Like a great black pit And the vermin of the world Inhabit it And its morals aren't worth What a pig could spit And it goes by the name Of London. At the top of the hole Sit the privileged few Making mock of the vermin In the lower zoo, Turning beauty into filth and greed. I too Have sailed the world, and seen its wonders For the cruelty of men Is as wondrous as Peru, But there's no place like London! Anthony looks at his friend, mystified by his grim reacti to the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your indulgence, Anthony ... My mind is far from easy. In these once familiar streets I feel shadows everywhere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shadows...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ghosts. Anthony looking at him, questioning. Todd continues quiet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a barber and his wife, And she was beautiful, A foolish barber and his wife, She was his reason and his life, And she was beautiful, And she was virtuous. And he was... (a breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naive. Anthony watches, rapt, as Todd remembers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Fifteen years before. Todd walks with his beautiful wife LUCY through a crowded flower market, a colorful explosion of blossoms. Lucy car their one-year-old baby, JOHANNA. Todd is almost unrecognizable to us, content and smiling. Chatting with his wife. Happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was another man who saw That she was beautiful, A pious vulture of the law, Who with a gesture of his claw Removed the barber from his plate. Then there was nothing but to wait And she would fall, So soft, So young, So lost, And oh, so beautiful!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: During the above, JUDGE TURPIN, an elderly man with a saturnine demeanor, eyes Lucy through the luxurious bunch of flowers. He stalks her, desiring her. With the Judge is his nefarious creature, BEADLE BAMFORD. Beadle is a large man, his florid nature and pink, powder face never quite disguising his lethality. The Judge whispers to the Beadle, indicating Todd. Then t Beadle and several policemen sweep in and drag Todd off. Judge moves in on Lucy like a predator. And we return to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the lady, sir ... did she succumb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that was many years ago... I doubt if anyone would know. A quiet beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I owe you my life, Anthony. If you hadn't spotted me, I would be lost on the ocean still ... Thank you. Todd picks up his duffel bag, preparing to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will I see you again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might find me, if you like, around Fleet Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until then, my friend. He offers his hand. Todd takes it and shakes. Then Todd quickly turns and goes. Anthony stands for a moment, saddened by the mysterious p that hangs over his friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd strides along, deep in thought. The emotions roiling within him finally seethe out in a dark mutter:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a hole in the world Like a great black pit And it's filled with people Who are filled with shit And the vermin of the world Inhabit it... He disappears down the street as the music THUNDERS--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --We ZOOM ahead of Todd -- cutting through the city at lightning pace down twisting alleys and up crowded boulev -- into tunnels and over bridges -- slashing through Lond at breakneck speed -- the insane explosion of music sendi us hurtling to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fleet Street. We see the exterior of Mrs. Lovett's pie shop. It is tatt and unloved by all. Yet it has a strange, ghostly presenc it. Imposing and dead at the same time. There is an exterior staircase leading up to a darkened second floor room with a window overlooking the street. The music slows and continues as we see Todd, standing in front of the shop, considering it deeply. The GENERAL we saw before passes, glancing at Todd. Here then gone. Todd finally strides to the shop and enters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the dusty counter is... MRS. LOVETT, a venal, vigorous and slatternly woman in he 40's. She is currently busy chopping a loathsome mess of suet w a wicked looking knife, her greasy hair hanging down over face.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The moment Todd enters -- and the bell at the door sounds her head snaps up and her eyes are on him like a bird of prey:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A customer! Todd is startled, starts to go--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait! What's yer rush? What's yer hurry? (She sticks the knife into the counter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gave me such a-- (Wipes her hands on her apron) )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fright. I thought you was a ghost. Half a minute, can'tcher? Sit! Sit ye down! (An order)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit! (He obeys)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I meant is that I Haven't seen a customer for weeks. Did you come here for a pie, sir? (Todd nods. She flicks a bit of dust off a pie with a rag)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do forgive me if me head's a little vague-- Ugh! (She plucks something off the pie, examines it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that? But you'd think we had the plague-- (She drops it on the floor and stamps on it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the way that people-- (She flicks something off the pie with her finger)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep avoiding-- (Spotting it moving)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you don't! (She smacks it with her hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heaven knows I try, sir! (Lifts her hand, looks at it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tsk! (She wipes it on the edge of the counter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there's no one comes in even to inhale--

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tsk! (She blows the last dust off the pie as she brings it to him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right you are, sir. Would you like a drop of ale? (Todd nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind you, I can't hardly blame them-- (Pouring a tankard of ale)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are probably the worst pies in London. I know why nobody cares to take them-- I should know, I make them. But good? No, The worst pies in London-- Even that's polite. The worst pies in London-- If you doubt it, take a bite. (He does. It's horrible)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that just disgusting? You have to concede it. It's nothing but crusting-- Here, drink this, you'll need it-- (She gives him the ale)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The worst pies in London. During the following, she slams lumps of dough on the cou and rolls them out, grunting frequently as she goes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And no wonder with the price of meat What it is-- (Grunt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you get it. (Grunt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never (Grunt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought I'd live to see the day Men'd think it was a treat Finding poor (Grunt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Animals (Grunt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wot are dying in the street. Mrs. Mooney has a pie shop, Does a business, but I noticed something weird-- Lately all her neighbors' cats have disappeared. (Shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have to hand it to her-- Wot I calls Enterprise, Popping pussies into pies. Wouldn't do in my shop-- Just the thought of it's enough to make you sick.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And I'm telling you them pussy cats is quick. (Leans on counter, exhausted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No denying times is hard, sir -- Even harder than The worst pies in London. Only lard and nothing more-- (As Todd gamely tries another mouthful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that just revolting? All greasy and gritty, It looks like it's molting, And tastes like-- Well, pity A woman alone With limited wind And the worst pies in London! (Sighs heavily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah sir, Times is hard. Times is hard. She finishes one of the crusts with a flourish as the mus ends. Todd, meanwhile, is gulping at his ale, trying to wash do Mrs. Lovett's hideous creation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me, dearie, it's going to take more than ale to wash that taste out. Come with me and we'll get you a nice tumbler of gin. She leads him through the curtains at the back of the pie shop and into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Her parlor is a wonder of seedy faux-middle class Victoriana. Little knickknacks, dusty plants and dingy doilies. There is a threadbare mauve sofa in front of a comfortable fire. A faded picture postcard of the seaside hangs on a wall. She goes to a sideboard and pours him a huge glass of gin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't this homey now? Me cheery wallpaper was a real bargain too, it being only partly singed when the chapel burnt down ....

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She hands him the gin. He gulps it down, washing the tast her pie out of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a good boy, now you sit down and warm your bones, you look chilled through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits before the fire:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that a room over the shop? If times are so hard, why don't you rent it out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances up at the roof, considering the room over the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up there? Oh, no one will go near it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to him, something a little intense and probing about her gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People think it's haunted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haunted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who's to say they're wrong? ... You see, years ago, something happened up there. Something not very nice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flickering flame from the fire begins to cast a more intense red glow on her face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a barber and his wife, And he was beautiful, A proper artist with a knife, But they transported him for life. (Sighs) And he was beautiful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music continues as she looks at him, again with that rather intense gaze:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barker, his name was -- Benjamin Barker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Transported? What was his crime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with an edge)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Foolishness. She turns again to the fire, the red glow bathing her fac she remembers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy is pacing, holding Baby Johanna to her closely. Lucy distraught, strained, tears in her eyes. As Lucy paces we notice the room is full of dead and dyin flowers: dozens of dried bouquets tossed aside and ignore

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had this wife, you see, Pretty little thing, Silly little nit Had her chance for the moon on a string-- Poor thing. Poor thing. Lucy moves to the window, looks out. She sees Judge Turpi and the Beadle waiting below. The Judge holds yet another bouquet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was this Judge, you see, Wanted her like mad, Every day he'd send her a flower, But did she come down from her tower? Sat up there and sobbed by the hour, Poor fool. Lucy moves away from the window, sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, but there was worse yet to come, Poor thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Beadle is leading a nervous Lucy along an exclusive street of dark stone mansions, grand but somehow menacing Lucy is wearing her best dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Beadle calls on her, all polite, Poor thing, poor thing. The Judge, he tells her, is all contrite, He blames himself for her dreadful plight She must come straight to his house tonight! Poor thing, poor thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Beadle ushers Lucy into a ballroom. She is shocked to a fancy-dress ball in progress. Masked couples swirl around the ballroom, their number sinisterly multiplied by the distorting mirrors that fram the room. The hanging chandeliers, draped in red cloth, c a disquieting incarnadine glow on the proceedings...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, when she goes there, Poor thing, poor thing, They're having this ball all in masks. Lucy wanders lost through the swirling dancers, they buff her, confusing her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no one she knows there, Poor dear, poor thing, She wanders tormented, and drinks, Poor thing. The Judge has repented, she thinks, Poor thing. "Oh, where is Judge Turpin?" she asks. The Beadle finds Lucy again and graciously gives her his leading her through the party. She is thankful for the salvation he provides. He brings her to Judge Turpin. The Judge descends on Lucy, raping her. The other guests crowd around ravenously, enjoying the spectacle. A feveri nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was there, all right-- Only not so contrite! She wasn't no match for such craft, you see,

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And everyone thought it so droll. They figured she had to be daft, you see, So all of `em stood there and laughed, you see, Poor soul! Poor thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NOOOOOOOO...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd's wild howl shatters the memory and tears us back to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Todd is bolting up from the sofa, tormented--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..... NOOOOOO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands for a terrible beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would no one have mercy on her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it is you -- Benjamin Barker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Lucy?! Where's my wife?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She poisoned herself. Arsenic from the apothecary on the corner. I tried to stop her but she wouldn't listen to me. And he's got your daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He? Judge Turpin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adopted her like his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd absorbs this sickening news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen years of sweating in a living hell on a false charge. Fifteen years dreaming that I might come home to find a loving wife and child...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat as he stares into the fire, madness and purpose creeping in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I can't say the years have been particularly kind to you, Mr. Barker, but you still--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not Barker. That man is dead. It's Todd now. Sweeney Todd ... And he will have his revenge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He continues with a chilling and quiet resolve as he star with unblinking eyes into the fire:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge Turpin and the Beadle will pay for what they did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. He finally turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First I must have my shop back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They emerge from the pie shop. She begins to scale the exterior staircase to the darkened second floor room. He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come along...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She continues up, he slowly follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A macabre shroud of dust and spider's webs. Furniture cov in sheets. A broken mirror on one wall. We hear footsteps approaching and then Mrs. Lovett enters The door creaks like a living thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to worry, a touch of oil will put that right. (she turns back to Todd) ... Nothing to be afraid of, love, come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves into the room. But Todd hesitates at the door, looking into the room. For him this is a truly haunted place.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, she kneels and pries loose a floorboard. Underneath there is a hidden area. Within that, something covered with a velvet cloth. She removes it and carefully unwraps it. Her touch is particularly gentle and respectf We discover it is a fine leather case. She looks at it fo beat. Then turns to him, dusting it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finally steps into the room, drawn toward the case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they came for the girl, I hid 'em. I thought, who knows? Maybe the silly blighter'll be back again. Cracked in the head, wasn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haunting music begins as she opens the case... And we see it contains a beautiful set of razors. He stands for a long moment, gazing down at his beloved razors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those handles is chased silver, ain't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silver, yes... These are my friends, See how they glisten. (He picks up a small razor) See this one shine, How he smiles in the light. My friend, my faithful friend. (Holding it to his ear, feeling the edge with his thumb) ) Speak to me friend, Whisper, I'll listen. (Listening) I know, I know-- You've been locked out of sight All these years-- Like me, my friend. Well, I've come home To find you waiting.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Home, And we're together, And we'll do wonders, Won't we? Mrs. Lovett leans over him, in her own kind of trance as well. They now sing simultaneously:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Picking out a larger razor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You there, my friend, Come, let me hold you. Now, with a sigh You grow warm In my hand, My friend, My clever friend. (Putting it back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rest now, my friends. Soon I'll unfold you. Soon you'll know splendors You never have dreamed All your days--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your friend too, Mr. Todd. If you only knew, Mr. Todd-- Ooh, Mr. Todd, You're warm In my hand. You've come home. Always had a fondness for you, I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --My lucky friends. Till now your shine Was merely silver. Friends, You shall drip rubies, You'll soon drip precious Rubies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never you fear, Mr. Todd, You can move in here, Mr. Todd. Splendors you never have dreamed All your days Will be yours. I'm your friend.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And you're mine. Don't they shine beautiful? Silver's good enough for me, Mr. T... The music continues quietly as Todd stares at one of his razors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me now... She goes. Todd finally picks up his biggest razor and slo opens it, looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At last my arm is complete again. And he remains standing. Exalted. Then-- In the shattered mirror on the wall he suddenly sees-- The distorted reflections of the Gentleman, the Banker, a the General, looking at him--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lift your razor high, Sweeney! Hear it singing, "Yes!" Sink it in the rosy skin Of righteousness! Todd turns to them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (variously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His voice was soft, his manner mild. He seldom laughed but he often smiled, He'd seen how civilized men behave. He never forgot and he never forgave, Not Sweeney, Not Sweeney Todd, The Demon Barber of Fleet Street. Todd pulls a sheet off Baby Johanna's cradle. A cloud of rises. The ghosts disappear in the cloud of dust and Todd stands alone, staring at the cradle, holding his razor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony, now out of his sailor's uniform, is walking alon the sidewalk near the Judge's mansion, absorbed in a copy Baedeker's London. He stops, lost, trying to get his bearings, studying his Then an unusual sound emerges through the normal cosmopol bustle. It is the sound of a woman humming. He looks up t see... JOHANNA, a 16-year-old girl with golden hair, beautiful a hauntingly sad. She sits at her window above, behind bars humming to herself as she does needlepoint. Anthony watches her, absolutely mesmerized. Johanna notices a Bird Seller passing. He carries a long, wooden pole with little bird cages attached.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green finch and linnet bird, Nightingale, blackbird, How is it you sing? How can you jubilate, Sitting in cages, Never taking wing? Outside the sky waits, Beckoning, beckoning, Just beyond the bars. How can you remain, Staring at the rain, Maddened by the stars? How is it you sing Anything? How is it you sing? Then ... she sees Anthony on the sidewalk below. Music continues. There is a long look between them. Her intense, melancholy expression moves him. She continues singing, the strange anguish and yearning o her words seem intended only for him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My cage has many rooms, Damask and dark. Nothing there sings, Not even my lark. Larks never will, you know, When they're captive.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Teach me to be more adaptive. Green finch and linnet bird, Nightingale, blackbird, Teach me how to sing. If I cannot fly, Let me sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then she turns away quickly, alarmed, when someone enters room. She looks terrified. Below, Anthony is concerned for her. He sees her move fro the window. He is craning to see better when a BEGGAR WOMAN -- a filt tendril of a woman, her foul clothes of rags like a secon skin -- suddenly thrusts her arm up from the curb, implor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alms! ... Alms! ... For a miserable woman On a miserable chilly morning... (Anthony drops a coin into her hand) Thank yer, sir, thank yer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am, could tell me whose house this is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the great Judge Turpin's house that is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the young lady who resides there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Johanna, his pretty little ward. Keeps her snug, he does, all locked up ... So don't you go trespassing there or it's a good whipping for you -- or any other young man with mischief on his mind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She suddenly leers into a lewd and demented assault:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Ow would you like a little muff, dear, A little jig jig A little bounce around the bush? Wouldn't you like to push me parsley?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: It looks to me, dear, Like you got plenty there to push. She grabs at Anthony's crotch -- Anthony starts back -- s turns away, instantly plaintive again, and appeals to oth pedestrians as she goes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alms! ... Alms!... For a desperate woman... Anthony considers the mansion. He sees a figure standing window, unclear behind the shutters, watching him. He sits on a bench outside the mansion and sings quietly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel you, Johanna, I feel you. I was half convinced I'd waken, Satisfied enough to dream you. Happily I was mistaken, Johanna! I'll steal you, Johanna, I'll steal you... Then the figure disappears from the window above. Anthony stands, waits. Then the doors to the mansion swing open.. Anthony is expecting Johanna... But it is Judge Turpin, the predator we met in Todd's flashback, who steps into the doorway. He seems a different man now. Paternal and warm, he smile and beckons to Anthony. Anthony hesitates, unsure. The Judge beckons again. Again warm smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, lad. Come in... Anthony goes into the mansion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge Turpin leads Anthony into the dark library, filled books. Anthony is looking around for Johanna. He is wary, this is all very strange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... you were looking for Hyde Park, you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's terribly large on the map but I keep getting lost...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, lad, sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony sits, uncomfortable, as the Judge pours two snift of brandy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's embarrassing for a sailor to lose his bearings, but, well, there you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then... The large form of the Beadle appears from the shadows. No introduction is made. Anthony glances to him, uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sailor, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. The "Bountiful" out of Plymouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing him a snifter of brandy) A sailor must know the ways of the world, yes? ... Must be practiced in the ways of the world ... Would you say you are practiced, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge moves to consider some beautiful volumes, bound the richest leather. He runs a finger along the spines of books; his large library of pornography.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes ... such practices ... the geishas of Japan ... the concubines of Siam .. the catamites of Greece ... the harlots of India ... I have them all here ... Drawings of them ....

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JUDGE (cont'd) (he turns again to Anthony)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... All the vile things you've done with your whores. Anthony is speechless. The Judge just smiles at him amiab

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think there's been some mistake--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I think not. You gandered at my ward, Johanna ... You gandered at her ... Yes, sir, you gandered. The Beadle moves behind Anthony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing nervously back at the Beadle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant no harm--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your meaning is immaterial. Mark me: if I see your face again on this street, you'll rue the day your bitch of a mother gave you birth. Anthony is stunned. The Judge proceeds with shocking veno

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Johanna isn't one of your bloody cock-chafers! My Johanna is not to be gandered at! He nods to the Beadle -- the Beadle instantly grabs Antho and brutally hauls him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Beadle drags Anthony through a rear door of the mansi and flings him into a filthy alley. Anthony pulls himself up. Stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hyde Park is that way, young sir ... A right and then a left, then straight on, you see? ...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BEADLE (cont'd) (points) ... Over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flustered, Anthony turns to look-- The instant Anthony's back is turned, the Beadle swings h lethal billyclub and SLAMS him from behind brutally, in t kidneys -- Anthony's knees buckle-- The Beadle then SLAMS Anthony across the back of the neck Anthony falls hard-- The Beadle then uses one dainty foot to roll Anthony over Anthony gazes up at him, panting for breath, in agony--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard Judge Turpin, little man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He presses the end of his billyclub into Anthony's forehe grinding it hard--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time it'll be your pretty brains all over the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that, the Beadle returns to the mansion and slams th door. Anthony slowly pulls himself to his knees, doubled over, coughing up blood. A long beat as Anthony gets his breath, wiping blood from face. Still doubled over, he sings with burning intensity:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll steal you, Johanna, I'll steal you! Do they think that walls can hide you? Even now I'm at your window. I am in the dark beside you, Buried sweetly in your yellow hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls himself up, every movement is agony. He makes hi way down the alley, leaning on the wall for support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music swells as Anthony emerges from the dark alley i the bright sunlight. He makes his way along the sidewalk:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel you, Johanna, And one day I'll steal you. Till I'm with you then, I'm with you there, Sweetly buried in your yellow hair...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soaring music continues as Anthony stops at a park ac the street from Turpin's mansion, bravely gazing up at Johanna's window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweeney Todd and Mrs. Lovett are moving quickly, she struggles to keep up with his long, loping stride. He car his razor case, she carries a shopping basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's here every Thursday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like clockwork. Eyetalian. All the rage he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for long.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ST. DUNSTAN'S MARKETPLACE DAY
dialogues.text: They round a corner and move into the bustling marketplac steady mercantile hum as the cries of merchants and wande coster-mongers fill the air. Todd and Mrs. Lovett move toward a hand-drawn caravan dominating one corner of the marketplace. It is painted l a Sicilian donkey cart and on its side a sign declaims: "Signor Adolfo Pirelli -- Haircutter to His Royal Majesty King of Naples."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Mr. T., do you really think you can do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By tomorrow they'll all be flocking to me like sheep to be shorn--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops abruptly when he sees-- The Beadle casually strolling through the crowd. Todd is transfixed, his ancient enemy so close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing the Beadle, pulling his arm) Come along now, dear, he might recognize you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will do what I have vowed to do ... (he continues to glare at the Beadle, his voice low) ... Come closer, my friend, closer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, TOBY -- a 13-year-old boy, a bit small for his age, malnourished and consumptively pale -- emerges from Pirel caravan. He bangs on a tin drum, drawing customers. A crowd begins to gather at the caravan as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen! May I have your attention, perlease? Do you wake every morning in shame and despair To discover your pillow is covered with hair Wot ought not to be there? Well, ladies and gentlemen, From now on you can waken at ease. You need never again have a worry or care, I will show you a miracle marvelous rare, Gentlemen, you are about to see something wot rose from the dead! (A woman gasps, he smiles and wiggles a finger no) On the top of my head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dramatically doffs his cap, revealing mountains of hai which cascade to his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Twas Pirelli's Miracle Elixir, That's wot did the trick, sir, True, sir, true. Was it quick, sir? Did it in a tick, sir? Just like an elixir Ought to do! (To a Bald Man) How about a bottle, mister? Only costs a penny, guaranteed. (Pours a drop on the bald man's head) Does Pirelli's

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Stimulate the growth, sir? You can have my oath, sir, 'Tis unique. (Applies the bald man's hand to the wet spot)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rub a minute, Stimulatin', i'n it? Soon you'll have to thin it Once a week! More customers are stepping up and buying bottles. Todd opens a bottle of the Elixir, takes a whiff. Disgust He smiles to Mrs. Lovett, his plan falling into place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly, to Mrs. Lovett)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me, ma'am, what's that awful stench?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we standing near an open trench?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to a woman in the crowd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be standing near an open trench! The crowd responds to Todd and Mrs. Lovett, looking askan and sniffing at the bottles. Toby nervously tries to dist them:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buy Pirelli's Miracle Elixir: Anything wot's slick, sir, Soon sprouts curls. Try Pirelli's! When they see how thick, sir, You can have your pick, sir, Of the girls! Want to buy a bottle, missus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sniffing bottle of Elixir)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sniffing another customer's bottle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smells like piss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smells like -- phew!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is piss. Piss with ink. The music speeds up -- Toby is getting desperate:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let Pirelli's Activate your roots, sir--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it off your boots, sir-- Eats right through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, get Pirelli's! Use a bottle of it! Ladies seem to love it--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flies do too! Suddenly, the curtains on the caravan are dramatically fl wide to reveal-- PIRELLI, a flamboyant Italian with a velvet suit, thick w hair and a dazzling smile. Pirelli poses splendidly for a moment. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Adolfo Pirelli, Da king of da barbers, da barber of kings, E buon giorno, good day, I blow you a kiss! (he does so)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I, da so-famous Pirelli, I wish-a to know-a Who has-a da nerve-a to say My elixir is piss! Who says this?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. (Todd moves forward boldly.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Mr. Sweeney Todd of Fleet Street. I have opened a bottle of Pirelli's elixir, and I say to you that it is nothing but an arrant fraud, concocted from piss and ink.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The crowd gasps. Pirelli is about to respond, outraged, b Todd continues--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And furthermore --   "signor" -- I have serviced no kings,   yet I wager I can shave a cheek with   ten times more dexterity that any   street mountebank. He snaps open his razor case and holds it up for the crow see, turning to display the wondrous razors:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see these razors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the crowd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The finest in England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glaring at Pirelli)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lay them against five pounds you are no match for me. You hear me, sir? Either accept my challenge or reveal yourself as a sham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bravo, bravo. The crowd is enjoying this now, whispering eagerly about bold challenge. In the crowd, we see a quick flash of the meek TOURIST we saw earlier. Pirelli studies the razors for a moment and then turns to crowd with a confident smile:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear zis foolish man? Watch and see how he will regret his folly! Music begins as Todd moves into action, preparing the challenge:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friends, who's for a free shave? Two men step forward. A plain wooden chair is brought for Todd as he moves into the boldest part of this plan... He carefully turns to ... The Beadle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will Beadle Bamford be the judge?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lovett's eyes shoot to Todd, alarmed-- The Beadle moves toward Todd .... Todd smiles amiably, but quivers internally at being so dreadfully close to his prey... Mrs. Lovett watches, concerned. Will the Beadle recognize features of Benjamin Barker...? Apparently not. The Beadle stops right before Todd and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad, as always, to oblige my friends and neighbors (to the crowd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Let the challenge commence! One man sits in Todd's plain chair as the other moves to elaborate chair on Pirelli's caravan. Pirelli shakes out fancy bib with a flourish and covers his man. Toby prepar Pirelli's ornate shaving supplies as Todd takes a plain t and tucks it around his man's neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fastest, smoothest shave is the winner. He blows his shrill whistle. Agitated music begins. Pirelli strops his razor quickly, Todd in a leisurely man Pirelli keeps glancing at Todd in various paranoid ways throughout, frightened of Todd's progress. He starts whip up lather rapidly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (while mixing furiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, signorini, signori, We mix-a da lather But first-a you gather Around, signorini, signori, You looking a man

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Who have had-a da glory To shave-a da Pope. Mr. Sweeney-so-smart-- (Splatters the customer with shaving cream)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I beg-a you pardon -- 'll Call me a lie, was-a only a cardinal-- Nope! It was-a da Pope! Unexpectedly, Todd still shows no signs of starting to sh his man. He merely watches Pirelli's performance. Mrs. Lo looks at him nervously, wishing he would get on with it. Pirelli, now feeling he can take his time, sings lyricall he lathers and shaves with rhythmic scrapes and elaborate gestures of wiping the razor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To shave-a da face, To cut-a da hair, Require da grace Require da flair, For if-a you slip, You nick da skin, You clip-a da chin, You rip-a da lip a bit Beyond-a repair! Todd strops his razor slowly and deliberately -- shoop, shoop, shoop -- disconcerting Pirelli and drawing the cro attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To shave-a da face Or even a part Widout it-a smart Require da heart. Not just-a da flash, It take-a panache, It take-a da passion For da art. Todd is unconcerned. He just continues to slowly strop hi razor -- shoop, shoop, shoop -- which flusters Pirelli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To shave-a da face, To trim-a da beard, To make-a da bristle Clean like a whistle, Dis is from early infancy Da talent give to me

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: By God! (Crosses   himself with his razor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It take-a da   skill, It take-a da   brains, It take-a da   will To take-a da   pains, It take-a da   pace, It take-a da   graaaaaace... While Pirelli holds this note elaborately, Todd, with a f deft strokes, quickly lathers his man's face, shaves him signals the Beadle to examine him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blowing whistle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The winner is Todd. Pirelli deflates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeling the customer's cheek)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smooth as a baby's arse! -- (to Todd) - - Well done, dear! The crowd laughs and applauds Todd as Pirelli goes to him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a profound bow)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I bow to a skill far defter than my own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The five pounds. Pirelli produces a distinctive chatelaine purse and remov five pound note, gives it to Todd:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, sir. And may the good Lord smile on you -- (a quick stab of a smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Until we meet again. He bows his head quickly and then moves away, beckoning t Toby:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're pulling out, sir?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Without warning, Pirelli SLAPS Toby viciously across the --Toby almost falls--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snarling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're pulling out, yes. Quickly. Mrs. Lovett has observed all of this as she moves away wi Todd, who is making his way inexorably toward the Beadle. Some eager customers surround Todd, among them is the TOURIST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Todd, sir, do you have an establishment of your own? Mrs. Lovett is on him like a hawk:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He certainly does. Sweeney Todd's Tonsorial Parlor -- above my meatpie emporium in Fleet Street. Todd has led them right to the Beadle:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thank you for your honest adjudication, sir. You are a paragon of integrity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I try to do my best for my friends and neighbors ... Your establishment is in Fleet Street, you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, Mr. Todd, you will surely see me there before the week is out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will be welcome, Beadle Bamford, and I guarantee to give you, without a penny's charge, the closest shave you will ever know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd and Mrs. Lovett are walking away from the marketplac She chatters happily:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Like to give me a coronary right there! What if he had recognized you! Lord, my heart was beating a mile a minute, just like a little finch it was. Aren't those lovely birds now? Always so twittery and happy... She continues chattering... But Todd is not listening. His eyes dart to the side to see-- The Gentleman is walking next to him, whispering, subtle, insinuating...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweeney pondered and Sweeney planned. Like a perfect machine 'e planned... The Banker moves in next to the Gentleman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbing the hook, baiting the trap, Setting it out for the Beadle to snap... The General joins them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slyly courted 'im, Sweeney did, Set a sort of a scene 'e did...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laying the trail, showing the traces, Letting it lead to higher places... Sweeney... The last word echoes ... And then they are gone ... disappearing from Todd's mind ... swallowed up by the cro of pedestrians... Todd looks to Mrs. Lovett and she continues chattering:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Suppose it's just me gentle heart, but I do hate to see a boy treated like that, no better than your Aunt Doreen's dog -- Mr. Todd, are you listening to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then his eyes dart again -- looking for the specters. only sees strangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johanna sits, framed by the window, quietly cutting out silhouettes. Aimless Victorian handicrafts. But we see there are tears in her eyes. She steals a glance across the room. We see a small hole the wallpaper. Through this hole, the Judge is watching h from another chamber. Lascivious. Perverse. Johanna finally stands and casually glances out from betw the shutters at her window. She sees... Anthony, standing at the park across the street, keeping his lonely vigil, gazing up at the mansion. She watches him for a moment and then makes her decision. moves to a table and opens a drawer. Reaches in and remov something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony sees a figure at the shutters -- then hears a clinking sound. Metal on pavement. He quickly moves across the street and looks... A key, dropped from above. He looks up to the shutters and smiles, then snatches up key and hurries off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peering through the shutters, Johanna watches him go. We linger on her face and then dissolve to another face, watching...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Her father. Todd's face, staring out the window, intense and brooding Seething with discontent. Mrs. Lovett chatters as she moves around behind him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It's not much of a chair, I'll grant, but it'll serve. Was me poor Albert's chair. Sat in it all day long he did, after his leg give out from the gout, poor dear. He moves from the window and paces like a caged tiger in small barber shop. Though it has been cleaned, it is still a spartan room. A tatty parlor chair. A large chest. A few counters with me bottles of tonsorial supplies. And his gleaming razors, always waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why doesn't the Beadle come? "Before the week is out," that's what he said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who says the week's out? It's only Tuesday. Todd moves away from her, she pursues, trying to calm and soothe him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy now. Hush, love, hush. Don't distress yourself, What's your rush? Keep your thoughts Nice and lush. Wait. (he continues to pace)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hush, love, hush. Think it through. Once it bubbles, Then what's to do? Watch it close. Let it brew. Wait. He does not respond. She dares to move closer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been thinking, flowers-- Maybe daisies-- To brighten up the room. Don't you think some flowers, Pretty daisies, Might relieve the gloom? Ah, wait, love, wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd sourly tosses himself into the chair, he picks up hi largest razor and looks at it intensely:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to razor) And the Judge? When will we get to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you think of nothing else? Always broodin' away on yer wrongs what happened heaven knows how many years ago... Don't you know, Silly man, Half the fun is to Plan the plan? All good things come to Those who can Wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her gentle words have calmed him considerably. She moves closer. Risks touching him softly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gillyflowers, maybe, `Stead of daisies... I don't know, though... What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Todd tilts the razor in his hand-- SUDDENLY -- the face of the GENTLEMAN -- a flash -- refle in the razor-- Then-- A bell rings from outside the shop -- the effect is elect -- Todd bolts up, senses alert -- Mrs. Lovett spins to th door--

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Todd holds his razor open as he moves strategically towar the door-- We hear footsteps ascending the stairs outside quickly-- Then-- Anthony enters, breathless--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Todd! Thank God I've found you -- (Todd turns, closing the razor, as Anthony sees Mrs. Lovett)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Oh, I'm sorry, excuse me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lovett, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pleasure, ma'am -- (continues to Todd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- You see, there's a girl who needs my help -- such a sad girl, and lonely, but beautiful too and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow down, Anthony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes a breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm sorry ... This girl has a guardian so tyrannical that he keeps her locked away. But then this morning she dropped this ... (produces the key)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It must be a sign that Johanna wants me to help her -- that's her name, Johanna -- and Turpin that of her guardian. A judge of some sort... Todd and Mrs. Lovett exchange a quick glance as Anthony continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I've met him, Mr. Todd, and he is - - unnatural ... Once he goes to court, I'm going to slip into the house and release her -- and beg her to come away with me. Tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, this is all terribly romantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but -- you see -- I don't know anyone in London -- (to Todd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and I need somewhere safe to bring her till I've hired a coach to take us to Plymouth. He looks at Todd deeply:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I could keep her here, just for an hour or two, I would forever be in your debt. Todd stares at him, his mind racing to figure out how thi new twist might aid in his plans. It is Mrs. Lovett who smoothly replies:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring her here, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, ma'am ... (to Todd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Mr. Todd? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl may come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking his hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, my friend. He goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems like the fates are favoring you at last, Mr. T. (Todd grunts, unhappy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, love? You'll have her back before the day is out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a few hours? Before he carries her off to the other end of England?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, him? Let him bring her here and then, since you're so hot for a little
(makes a throat-cutting gesture)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- that's the throat to slit, dear. Todd moves again to his post at the window, he stares out deep in thought. Meanwhile, she happily moves around the shop, straighteni things up and trying to make it all a bit more cozy:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor little Johanna. All those years without a scrap of motherly affection. Well, we'll soon see to that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alert, sees something)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this? Mrs. Lovett joins him at the window. Below, they see Pire approaching with Toby in tow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that face, he's up to mischief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go -- keep the boy below with you. She nods and scurries out. We go with her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Mrs. Lovett quickly moves down the steps outside the barber shop to greet Pirelli and Toby as they are about t ascend. We see a new sign on the stairs: "Sweeney Todd's Tonsoria Parlor."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Signora, is Mr. Todd at home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plying his trade upstairs, don'tcher know ... (she stands on the staircase, blocking their way, looking at Toby)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MRS. LOVETT (cont'd) ... Would you look at it, now! Don't look like it's had a kind word since half past never!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Pirelli) You wouldn't mind if I gave him a nice juicy meat pie, would yer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatient) Yes, yes, whatever you like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pirelli climbs the stairs, as she takes Toby by the hand leads him toward the pie shop door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with me now. Your teeth is strong, I hope?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go into the pie shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd is standing, arms folded. Waiting. Pirelli enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Todd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Signor Pirelli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reverting to his natural Irish) Call me Danny. Daniel Higgins' the name when it's not professional ... I'd like me five quid back, if'n ya don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you entered into our little wager on false pretenses, me friend ... And so you might remember to be more forthright in the future, you'll be handing over half your profits to me, share and share alike...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Todd shakes his head, amused, and begins to turn away whe Pirelli says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Mr. Benjamin Barker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lovett hands Toby one of her grisly pies, he devours eagerly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my boy, tuck in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But her attention is almost entirely on the roof above .. the muffled voices .... the sound of shoes walking... Her eyes keep darting up as she chatters distractedly wit Toby:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like to see a man with a healthy appetite. Reminds me of my dear Albert, like to gorge himself to bloatation, he did. He didn't have your nice full head though--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To tell the truth -- (he pulls off the wig which covers his own short-cropped hair) -- it gets awful hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pirelli is expansively strolling around the shop, taking all in, savoring every second:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... yes, this will do very nicely ... You don't remember me. Well, why should you? I was just a down and out Irish pug you hired for a couple of weeks -- sweeping up hair and the like -- (He picks up one of Todd's razors) But I remember these -- And how could I ever forget you, Benjamin Barker?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PIRELLI (cont'd) I would sit right there and watch you, and dream of the day I could be a proper barber meself ... You might say you were an inspiration to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, do we have a deal, or should I run down the street for me pal Beadle Bamford? What do you say to that now, Mr. Sweeney T--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without a word of warning-- Like a thunderbolt-- Todd is on him. He leaps across the shop and brutally grabs Pirelli by th neck -- violently strangling him -- Pirelli is surprising strong and puts up a desperate struggle -- they thump awkwardly around the shop--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lovett hears the muffled sounds of the struggle abov She nervously begins to shift and clang some things aroun she cleans the counter, trying to cover the sound, chattering:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My my my, always work to be done. Spic- and-span, that's my motto. Cleanliness is next to whatever-it-is. So, ah, how did you end up with that dreadful Eyetalian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still eating happily) Got me from the workhouse 'e did. Been there since I was born. Got no mum, got nobody. A wasted soul, that's what I am -- (a sudden, urgent thought) -- Oh God! He's got an appointment with his tailor--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bolts up, clearly terrified of Pirelli--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's late, he'll blame me--!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait--!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he is gone--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby vaults up the stairs to the barber shop--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd is standing calmly when Toby bursts in--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Signor, you got an appointment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops when he realizes Pirelli is nowhere to be seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Signor Pirelli has been called away. You better run after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, sir. I better wait for him here or it'll be a lashing. He's a great one for the lashings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves past Todd to the large chest and sits-- Only now do we see one of Pirelli's hands protruding from chest, dangling limply. Toby doesn't notice it. Todd at this moment, however, doe He smiles nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, hmmm, Mrs. Lovett gave you a pie, did she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a real lady. Model of all true Christian virtue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Pirelli's hand ... twitches. Toby doesn't notice. Todd does, stares at it anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That she is ... that she is. But if I know a growing boy, there's still room for some more pie, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say, sir -- (pats his stomach) -- An aching void.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pirelli's hand begins to twitch more desperately now, perilously close to where Toby's hand rests...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why don't you run downstairs and wait for your master there? There'll be another pie in it for you, I'm sure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pirelli's hand is twitching closer to Toby's now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I should stay here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a   sudden inspiration) I know   -- why don't you tell Mrs. Lovett   I said to give you a nice big tot of   gin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaps up) Gin, sir?! Thanking you kindly, sir! You're a Christian indeed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He races out happily and clatters down the stairs. A beat as Todd gets his breath. Then he goes to the trunk, leans down to open it, the cam follows him down and up again, when he rises-- The GENTLEMAN is standing right behind him! Todd turns. The Gentleman's face is completely impassive. He is not spectral. He does not disappear. He just stands there. Todd looks at him. Then the Gentleman's eyes slowly move to a counter... Todd follows his look to see... His largest razor. A long beat as Todd looks at the razor.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The point of no return. Todd strides to the razor and he snaps it open with a sha quick flick of his wrist-- Then he moves to the chest and-- With great ferocity he hauls Pirelli up-- Pirelli's eyes snap open-- And Todd SLASHES his throat-- The piercing factory whistle SCREAMS-- Todd remains standing over Pirelli as the painful whistle echoes into music... We see that the Gentleman is still standing there, watchi Todd...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hands were quick, his fingers strong. It stung a little but not for long. The dashing Oxford Student is now leaning against a wall, arms folded, looking at Todd...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And those who thought him a simple clod Were soon reconsidering under the sod... The Tourist stands by the window...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consigned there with a friendly prod From Sweeney Todd, The Demon Barber of Fleet Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See your razor gleam, Sweeney, Feel how well it fits As it floats across the throats Of hypocrites. The last word echoes to silence as we cut to: A high-angle shot of the room. The ghosts are gone. Todd stands alone over Pirelli's body. Blood dripping fro his razor. Drip. Drip. Drip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge Turpin lurks over the proceedings. He sits, the personification of power, very high at the bench. He glares down a wasted wretch of a BOY. The Beadl stands next to the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the second time, sir, that you have been brought before this bench. Though it is my earnest wish to ever temper justice with mercy, your persistent dedication to a life of crime is an abomination before God and man. He places a black cloth on his head:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I therefore sentence you to hang by the neck until you are dead and may the Lord have mercy on your soul. The wretched boy collapses in sobs. The Beadle is pleased with the verdict. The Judge removes the black cloth and tosses it casually his desk:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This court is adjourned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge and the Beadle walk away from the impressive edifices of the Old Bailey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, your Honor. Just the sentence we wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was he guilty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if he didn't do it, he's surely done something to warrant a hanging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What man has not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No matter -- Come, walk home with me. I have news for you, my friend. In order to shield her from the evils of this world, I have decided to marry my dear Johanna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, sir, happy news indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strange, though, when I offered myself to her she showed a certain ... reluctance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Beadle proceeds with exquisite and obsequious delicac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, my lord, May I request, my lord, Permission, my lord, to speak? Forgive me if I suggest, my lord, You're looking less than your best, my lord, There's powder upon your vest, my lord. And stubble upon your cheek, And ladies, my lord, are weak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they round a corner, the Judge feels his chin:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stubble, you say? Perhaps at times I am a little overhasty with my morning ablutions...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerily) Fret not though, my lord, I know a place, my lord, A barber, my lord, of skill. Thus armed with a shaven face, my lord, Some eau de cologne to brace my lord And musk to enhance the chase, my lord, You'll dazzle the girl until She bows to your every will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A barber, eh? Take me to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am honored, my lord. His name is Todd ... Sweeney Todd. And he is the very last word in barberin'. They head off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lovett is pouring Toby a glass of gin, not his first He gulps down the gin between ravenous bites of another m pie as she nervously glances up to the ceiling, wondering what the hell is going on up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to slow down a bit, lad. It'll go to your head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weaned on the stuff, I was. They used to give it to us at the workhouse, so's we could sleep. Not that you'd ever want to sleep in that place, ma'am. Not with the things wot happen in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's nice, dear ... I think I'll just pop in on Mr. Todd for a tick. You'll be all right here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave the bottle. She goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lovett enters. Todd is methodically cleaning his raz

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gawd, the lad is drinking me out of house and home, how long until Pirelli gets back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't be back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (instantly suspicious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. T., you didn't!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He casually points the razor toward the chest. She lifts the lid and sees Pirelli's body at the bottom o the chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spinning on Todd) You're barking mad! Killing a man wot done you no harm!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He recognized me from the old days. He tried to blackmail me -- half my earnings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved) Oh well, that's a different matter! For a moment there I thought you'd lost your marbles!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks into the chest again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooooh! All that blood! Enough to make you come all over gooseflesh, ain't it? Poor bugger. Oh, well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to close the chest, then has an idea. She reaches in and rummages around the body. Pulls out Pirelli's chatelaine purse, then drops the lid of the che

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking through purse) Three quid! Well, waste not, want not, I always say... (she tucks the purse into her dress) ... Now what are we going to do about the boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops, looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, we don't need to worry about him, he's a simple thing. I'll pawn him off with some story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cold)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send him up, woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Mr. T., surely one's enough for today. Don't want to indulge yourself, after all ... (she busily starts to straighten up the room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... 'Sides, I was thinking about hiring a lad to help around the shop, me poor knees not being what they used to be. Todd sighs and moves to his familiar post at the window:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything you say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Course we'll have to stock up on the gin, the boy drinks like a Barbary sailor-- Todd suddenly gasps -- a great, shocking intake of breath his whole body tenses like iron-- Mrs. Lovett spins to him--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge. Mrs. Lovett hurries to the window-- Below, they can see the Judge and the Beadle approaching. They see them exchanging a few words and then the Beadle moves off as the Judge approaches the shop-- Todd whispers, his eyes blazing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Justice ... Justice. Mrs. Lovett gives him a quick kiss and then very quickly leaves. A beat as Todd prepares himself. He turns from the window and looks around the shop, shift nervously. Now that his great moment of revenge is at han he doesn't quite know what to do with himself.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He snatches up his large razor, coils by the door, ready attack. No. He wants to savor this. He quickly moves and the razor down. Finally he just stands. All his demons settling into a bizarre sort of calm. He hears the Judge's footsteps approaching on the stairs. Then the Judge enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Todd? Todd slowly turns:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At your service ... An honor to receive your patronage, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know me, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a polite bow)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who in this wide world is not familiar with the honored Judge Turpin? The Judge grunts and glances around the shop:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These premises are hardly prepossessing and yet the Beadle tells me you are the most accomplished of all the barbers in the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is gracious of him, sir ... (indicates for the Judge to sit)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Sit, if you please, sir. Sit. The Judge settles into the parlor chair as music begins..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what may I do for you today, sir? A stylish trimming of the hair? A soothing skin massage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, sir, a man infatuate with love, Her ardent and eager slave. So fetch the pomade and pumice stone And lend me a more seductive tone,

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A sprinkling perhaps of French cologne, But first, sir, I think -- a shave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The closest I ever gave. He whips a sheet over the Judge, then tucks the bib in. T Judge hums, flicking imaginary dust off the sheet; Todd whistles gaily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in a merry mood today, Mr. Todd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mixing lather)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Tis your delight, sir, catching fire From one man to the next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Tis true, sir, love can still inspire The blood to pound, the heart leap higher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What more, what more can man require--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Than love, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More than love, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah yes, women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty women. The Judge hums jauntily, Todd whistles and starts stroppi his razor rhythmically. He then lathers the Judge's face. Still whistling, Todd stands back to survey the Judge, wh now totally relaxed, eyes closed. Todd goes to his razor and picks it up, sings to it gentl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now then, my friend. Now to your purpose. Patience, enjoy it. Revenge can't be taken in haste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opening his eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make haste, and if we wed, You'll be commended, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord... (Goes to him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who, may it be said, Is your intended, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My ward. A shocked tremor through Todd -- as the Judge closes his again and settles in comfortably...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And pretty as a rosebud. The music rises...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty as her mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mildly puzzled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? What was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, nothing, sir. Nothing. May we proceed?
